html:
Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈker.toː/, [ˈkɛr.t̪oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈt͡ʃer.to/, [ˈt͡ʃɛr.t̪ɔ]
  • Audio (Classical)
    		(file)

Etymology 1[edit]

From certus (“resolved, certain”) +‎ -ō.

Alternative forms[edit]

  • certor

Verb[edit]

certō (present infinitive certāre, perfect active certāvī, supine certātum); first conjugation

  2. I fight, wrestle.
  3. I contend, compete, race.
  4. I struggle, strive.
  5. (military) I fight it out.
  6. (law) I dispute.
  7. (with infinitive) I try hard.

2At least one rare poetic syncopated perfect form is attested.

Synonyms[edit]
  • (fight): bellō
  • (contend): bellō
Derived terms[edit]
  • certābundus
  • certāmen
  • certātim
  • certātiō
  • certātor
  • certātus
  • certim
  • certor
  • concertō
  • dēcertō
  • incertō
  • supercertō
 
Descendants[edit]
  • Albanian: qërtoj
  • Aromanian: ntsertu, ntsirtari
  • Italian: certare
  • Portuguese: certar
  • Romanian: certa, certare

Etymology 2[edit]

From certus +‎ -ō.

Adverb[edit]

certō (comparative certius, superlative certissimē)

  2. certainly, surely
  3. with certainty, without doubt
Synonyms[edit]
  • certē

Etymology 3[edit]

See the etymology of the main entry.

Adjective[edit]

certō

  1. dative masculine singular of certus
  2. dative neuter singular of certus
  3. ablative masculine singular of certus
  4. ablative neuter singular of certus

References[edit]

  • Professor Kidd, et al. Collins Gem Latin Dictionary. HarperCollins Publishers (Glasgow: 2004). →ISBN. page 54.
